s.text: To clone the complete NRG1 ORF, HZ032 and HZ033 were used to PCR from genomic DNA the complete wild-type NRG1 from -1119 to +719.
This discrepancy between our findings and previous results can be explained by the fact that Park et al [ 11] used 10-fold more GST-Nrg1 in their binding studies than we did.
RNA was separated by electrophoresis on 1% agarose-formaldehyde gels, transferred to membrane and blotted with specific radio-labeled probes.
We found that an nrg1? mutant was able to grow on YP sucrose plus 2-DG, suggesting that nrg1? mutants are indeed defective for glucose repression.

We also tested growth of these strains on YP galactose + 2-DG plates and found that only the triple mutant was able to grow, albeit weakly, on this medium, perhaps because galactose is a poor carbon source (data not shown).

When glucose is present in the growth media, transcription of a large number of genes encoding products involved in the metabolism of alternative carbon sources is repressed (for reviews, see [ 1, 2, 3].
The Swi/Snf complex is required for normal levels of expression of SUC2 when cells are grown in low glucose.
The Swi/Snf complex is required for normal levels of expression of SUC2 when cells are grown in low glucose.

Consistent with previously published results, a mig1? mutant had a nine- to-fourteen fold increase in SUC2 mRNA levels while a mig2? mutant had no detectable defect in glucose repression of SUC2 [ 4, 12].
In general, multiple mutations caused greater derepression, up to 79-fold for the triple mutant, nrg1? mig1? mig2? (Figure 3A).
Under repressing conditions (2% glucose), the level of SUC2 mRNA was increased by two-to-four fold in an nrg1? strain compared to a wild-type control (Figure 3A).
In general, multiple mutations caused greater derepression, up to 79-fold for the triple mutant, nrg1? mig1? mig2? (Figure 3A).
This discrepancy between our findings and previous results can be explained by the fact that Park et al [ 11] used 10-fold more GST-Nrg1 in their binding studies than we did.
In general, multiple mutations caused greater derepression, up to 79-fold for the triple mutant, nrg1? mig1? mig2? (Figure 3A).
In general, multiple mutations caused greater derepression, up to 79-fold for the triple mutant, nrg1? mig1? mig2? (Figure 3A).
SUC2 mRNA levels in double and triple mutant combinations.

To assess the role of Nrg1 relative to the two other factors known to be required for glucose repression, Mig1 and Mig2, we compared the mutant phenotypes caused by nrg1?, mig1?, and mig2?, as well as testing combinations of these deletions.
SUC2 mRNA levels in double and triple mutant combinations.

To assess the role of Nrg1 relative to the two other factors known to be required for glucose repression, Mig1 and Mig2, we compared the mutant phenotypes caused by nrg1?, mig1?, and mig2?, as well as testing combinations of these deletions.
SUC2 mRNA levels in double and triple mutant combinations.
SUC2 mRNA levels in double and triple mutant combinations.

To assess the role of Nrg1 relative to the two other factors known to be required for glucose repression, Mig1 and Mig2, we compared the mutant phenotypes caused by nrg1?, mig1?, and mig2?, as well as testing combinations of these deletions.
To sensitize the screen, we used an allele of SUC2, SUC2-36, that allows an elevated level of SUC2 transcription in the absence of Swi/Snf [ 24].
Genetic screens have identified a large number of genes, named SNF (Sucrose Non-Fermenting) that are required for derepression of SUC2 transcription in the absence of glucose [ 16, 17, 18].
